column1: The fibre of a map \( \varphi\colon S \to T \)

column2: Let \(\varphi\colon G \to G'\) be a homomorphism. This relation is usually denoted by \(\equiv\) \[ a \equiv b \text{ if } \varphi(a) = \varphi(b)\]

column1: Let \(\varphi\colon G \to G'\) be a homomorphism with Kernel N. The set of elements of the form \(an\) is denoted by \(aN\) and is called a coset of N in G:
column2: \[aN = \{g \in G \mid g = an \text{ for some } n \in N \}\]
Let G, G' be groups. A homomorphism \(\varphi\colon G \to G'\) be any map satisfying the rule \[\varphi(ab) = \varphi(a)\varphi(b)\]
A group homomorphism \(\varphi\colon G \to G'\) carries the identity to the identity and the inverses to the inverses. \[\varphi(1_G) = 1_{G'} \text{ and } \varphi(a^{-1}) = \varphi(a)^{-1}\]

column1: The image of a homomorphism \(\varphi\colon G \to G'\)
column2: \[\text{im} \varphi =  \{x \in G' \mid x = \varphi(a) \text{ for some } a \in G\}\] and it is a subgroup of G'
Let A be a (square) n X n matrix. If there a matrix \(A^{-1}\) such that \(A^{-1}A = I_n = AA^{-1}\) then \(A^{-1}\) is called the inverse of A. It is unique if it exists.

column1: The product of invertible matrices is invertible

column2: Let M,M' be m X n and n X p matrices. \(M = [A \mid B] \text{ and } M' = [{A' \over B'}]\) where A has r columns and A' has r rows where r < n. Then the product is \(MM' = AA' + BB'\)
